TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 21 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Ex-Servicemen & Women's Pension Association is a body formed for the express purpose of obtaining a Service pension for all Ex-Service personnel at sixty years of age for men and fifty-five years of age for women regardless of where they served during the 1939-45 war.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should give urgent consideration to a favourable decision to the granting of the Service pension to all ex-Service personnel who served their country in time of need and who did not serve overseas through no fault of their own. The Service Pension is presently only granted to returned ex-Service Personnel.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MASON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 86 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

a. Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

b. The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
c. The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognize that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 9 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within four years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Our petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
The Clerk-A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving 'property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I preface my question by referring the Minister to the explanation given in the current issue of the Australian Bureau of Statistics publication Social Indicators of the Bureau's inability to measure poverty. At page 154 it states:

QUESTION.PARA: Although difficult methodological problems are involved in the compilation of equivalence scales, the concept (of equivalence scales) is central to wefare-oriented income analysis and particularly to any attempts to measure poverty. The inability to undertake analysis of adjusted incomes leaves many welfare questions unanswered.

In view of that statement, does the Minister consider that what are called the basic tools of measurement in social sciences are in fact capable of providing us with accurate measurements of social conditions? Further, does the Minister not consider the accurate measurement of poverty to be essential to government's financial planning?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's question highlights a very real difficulty in that area, and that is to put a precise figure on what is to be described as poverty. Obviously, it would simplify social planning and, indeed, economic planning if one were able to be quite categorical in terms of the money amounts which might be required by any particular person in a certain situation to maintain a decent, minimum standard for which it might be thought the taxpayer should be responsible. The question in fact raises some of the factors which make it genuinely difficult. The honourable senator specifically referred to equivalence scales. My recollection is that the original work on poverty measurement done by Professor Henderson, which is often referred to in this place, and indeed in debates on social security matters, relied on equivalence scales which were the result of United States research, I think based in New York. There has always been some question as to how relevant those equivalence scales are in the Australian context. It is known to the Senate, because my predecessor indicated it, that the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat has been doing work in this area. As I understand it, that work has included discussions between the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat and the Australian Bureau of Statistics on the difficult question of equivalence.

ANSWER.PARA: I anticipated that the draft report, which I have received recently but have not yet had a chance to peruse, includes advice on the question of equivalence and suggestions as to what might be regarded as appropriate equivalence scales in Australia. Not having had the opportunity of reading that draft report, I am not in a position to give any detailed comment and I do not wish to speculate. I can say with very real certainty that whatever is determined by any inquiry there will be genuine debate of both an academic and political nature on the correctness or otherwise of the equivalence scales or on any other aspect of poverty measurement which might be brought forward.

The matter might be summarised by saying that there will be a completely individual result in terms of the precise amount of money required by an individual to maintain a reasonable standard for that individual. Whilst the tools of the Commonwealth Statistician will no doubt be absolutely essential to our work in the social security area, in the end political judgments will have to be made. I am sure that, however carefully they are made and however much attention is paid to the available statistical data, there will be vigorous political debate about whether we are hitting the target precisely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs acknowledge that, as a result of the Lynch Committee's decision to abandon the collection of unemployment statistics by the Commonwealth Employment Service, there will be no way of monitoring Aboriginal unemployment which, in some communities, exceeds 80 per cent of the available work force? Is it the Government's intention to conceal this situation or will some accurate method of measuring Aboriginal employment be introduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions stated:

ANSWER.PARA: The regular collection and publication of CES statistics of persons registered for unemployment and of unfilled vacancies will be terminated . . .

The CES figures provided the only data on Aboriginal unemployment but they were deficient in a number of important ways. Firstly, the identification of people registering for employment was dependent upon visual identification by CES staff. That is not an adequate means of identifying who is an Aboriginal. Secondly, the statistics did not include those who, by reason of their geographic location, did not have access to CES facilities. The honourable senator may have referred to this at various times in the chamber. Thirdly, Aboriginals with either literacy problems or an inability to understand the required administrative procedures often do not register with the CES. Fourthly, the CES statistics did not include Aboriginals looking for part time work. I have been looking at some of the Hansard records of past debates. I noticed that many members of the Australian Labor Party have drawn attention in the past to the inadequacies of the collection of statistics by the CES. The Australian Bureau of Statistics monthly labour force survey, for technical reasons, cannot provide information on this issue either. As a result of this, officers from the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs are considering other means by which information on the level of unemployment among Aboriginals may be obtained. I agree with the honourable senator that it is desirable that we have some of this information. I think we should acknowledge the deficiencies in the information we had. We should also acknowledge that unemployment is high. I will pursue these opportunities with my colleague and his Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce notice an article in the Canberra Times by Mr Frank Cranston entitled 'Intending tourists warned off Australia'? In view of the tremendous importance of tourism to Tasmania, will the Government undertake a promotion campaign which will support Australia's need to be a reliable country which welcomes tourists but which will also allow them to go home? Will the Government stress in any such campaign the great importance to Australia of tourism as a generator of urban and regional employment? Will the Government hold talks with the Australian Council of Trade Unions in an attempt to avoid the dangerously high level of strikes presently threatening business generally but the tourist industry in particular?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can appreciate the honourable senator's concern about the tourist industry and the possible detrimental effects of strike action. I think there would be no dispute around the chamber that the tourist industry is of considerable economic importance to Australia. We are a country which sends many people overseas, and that of course has foreign exchange implications. For that reason alone I think it is generally desirable that we should be attracting visitors to this country. Australia's tourist record is very good at the moment and is improving. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, who has taken a great interest in this area, is reasonably pleased with the tourist situation in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I did have my attention drawn to an article in the Canberra Times which referred to intending tourists being warned off Australia. I am not in a position to confirm or to deny that travel agents overseas are warning people about coming to Australia or are avoiding sending people to Australia because of the risk that they will be stranded here. But I suggest to the honourable senator that what is required in this area is not a campaign to support Australia's need to allow tourists to go home when they have finished their visits here but an actual ability for tourists to go home when they have finished their visits here. I would have thought it should again be accepted all round the chamber that it is not in Australia's interest to see Australians or non-Australians stranded here or overseas because of strike action. The general industrial relations policy of this Government, which is aimed at the reduction of industrial conflict and which requires the co-operation of the Australian people, is one which, I trust, will reduce the problem to which the honourable senator referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, who is also a member of the Cabinet. I say by way of background that I am aware that many similar questions have been asked and that these proceedings are being broadcast to the Minister's home State, Western Australia, for breakfast. Is the Minister aware that wool growers are claiming that they contributed money to the establishment of the Australian Wool Testing Authority and that, as a consequence, they and not the Government are the owners of it? If the Authority is to be sold, who will get the money-the rightful owners, the Authority, or the Government? Finally, why did the Government not dispense with the Australian Wool Measurement Standards Authority, which the industry regards as unnecessary, instead of selling off the very viable Australian Wool Testing Authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator McAuliffe for drawing the attention of honourable senators to the fact that it is breakfast time in Western Australia. The people whom I represent and who might have their radios tuned to Question Time deserve slightly better treatment than is often afforded them in this place. Senator McAuliffe has shown a sensitivity to the people of Western Australia which is unusual for members of this party. I congratulate him for it.
—The best friends that Western Australians have are Queenslanders.

—I note that Senator McAuliffe is talking as a Queenslander and not as a member of the Australian Labor Party, so I withdraw my previous remarks. Senator McAuliffe drew attention to the fact that there have been several questions on this subject. I am aware that various claims have been made about the Australian Wool Testing Authority and that some representations have been made about its sale. As I have already indicated to the Senate, the Minister for Primary Industry, in carrying out the decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions in this area, has indicated that he will proceed in consultation with the Australian Wool Corporation.

ANSWER.PARA: I indicated yesterday that I thought it would not be sensible of me to go into more detail pending the Minister's return to Australia and his taking up of that commitment. I am quite sure that the points made by Senator McAuliffe will be taken into account in looking at how this matter should be approached. Of course, the Government is not seeking to take funds which have been contributed by other people. It is merely trying to reduce the amount of government administration in this country, not the benefits which flow to the people of Australia. I will certainly draw the points raised by Senator McAuliffe to Mr Nixon's attention. I have little doubt that the facts he has raised concerning the contributions by growers and so on are well known to the Minister and would have been in his mind in making his decision to proceed in consultation with the Corporation.

As to whether we should dispense with other elements in the wool testing area, I am grateful that the honourable senator from Queensland, who has a close interest in financial matters, should put forward suggestions for further economies which might be effected. I will see that they are referred to Sir Phillip Lynch with a view to examination because the Government has not completed its work in this area. The Government always wishes to be alert for other areas of saving which might be effected. If members of the Opposition can make sensible suggestions about that, so much the better. I say that without wishing to give any commitment that there should be any interference with that particular Authority. I am not so well advised of the matter to be able to say that the suggestion put forward by Senator McAuliffe has any merit. I simply say that I will refer it to the Minister for consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I preface it by referring to the many letters of protest received by honourable senators regarding the proposed draft regulations of the National Health and Medical Research Council. In this connection, will the Minister give his assurance that vitamin and/or mineral preparations will be in no way restricted unless such preparations in the recommended doses can be shown to be intrinsically dangerous to health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred in her question to the many letters of protest that have been received. I think all honourable senators would have received many letters of protest on this subject. As one who answers all those letters, I can say that I have signed my name many hundreds of times. Since all the letters of protest were in exactly the same wording and form, I hope that my correspondents will not be upset that all my responses were in exactly the same wording and in exactly the same form. They include a copy of a Press release issued by the Minister for Health which really attempts to set out what the situation is-that is, that a draft standard has been circulated for public discussion on the basis that by opening up the public discussion and getting expressions of view, the Government will be in a position better able to understand what the public wishes or feels on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked whether I could give an assurance relating to the future availability of vitamins and minerals. Of course, it is not within my capacity to give such an assurance. That would have to come from the Minister whom I represent. I draw the honourable senator's attention to the Press statements made already by Mr MacKellar in which he has made it clear that what has been released is something for public discussion and that he is anxious to receive as many expressions of public view as he can. Only at that stage will he come to some decision as to whether, if at all, some draft standard needs to be put down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was sponsoring the letter campaign? Does the Government know?
—I can only surmise; I believe there may be some people with vested interests involved. Nevertheless, I am interested to consider those letters on their merit.
—Marcus Blackmore has some views on this, hasn't he?

—Whether Mr Marcus Blackmore is the person responsible is something Senator Mulvihill may wish to tell me. I have seen some recent Press statements from the Minister for Health which I interpreted as being along the lines set out by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. If that is the case, the kinds of assurances she is seeking may already have been given.

—Has the Minister for National Development and Energy noted that construction of a major nuclear power-house planned for Brittany in France has been cancelled following vigorous and widespread citizen protest and that other nuclear power plant projects in France have been postponed until national referenda can be held? Is this the beginning of a major reversal of policy in France against nuclear energy and is not that trend also evident already in Japan? Since both these nations were once seen as major customers for Australian uranium and since other less scrupulous customers without doubt want our uranium for manufacturing bombs, will the Government now take positive steps to withdraw its support from the dangerous, pollutant, uneconomic and thoroughly discredited nuclear power industry by refusing any further development of uranium mining in this country? Will the Government commence this new policy immediately by effectively preventing any further exploitation for uranium of the existing Kakadu National Park and projected extensions of the park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I heard on the radio news that there was to be some postponement of the construction of a nuclear power station in France and that there was a suggestion that under the new Mitterrand regime there would be no progress on the nuclear campaign in France without a referendum. The background that honourable senators should understand is that France has projected that 50 per cent of its electric power generation will be provided by nuclear power by 1985 and that that percentage will increase from then. I am unable to say what will happen. I can say only that in France if, indeed, there is a decision to change course, there will be a major infrastructure problem with that change if France is to go to, say, coal because the lead times for power stations are eight to 10 years. I cannot venture an opinion, nor should I, upon either the practicability of proposals or the politics of another nation.

ANSWER.PARA: I have to say to the honourable senator in all good faith that some time ago I said-I did not say it with whimsy-that I saw on a wall in, I think, America, graffiti which read: 'Ban all nuclear power generation'. Someone else had written: 'Yes, and let all the illegitimates freeze to death in the dark'. I substituted a euphemism. There is a terribly important message in that. Most of those who understand the problem of providing alternative energy in this world believe two things. The first is that it will not be possible totally to solve the alternative energy problem by either the use of renewable energy or the major use of coal. The second point is that if it were possible to achieve the necessary coal power generation on the massive scale that is envisaged-that would involve shifting something like 1,000 million tonnes of coal a year by sea-the burning of that coal would create a world pollution potential and a threat to health of a magnitude that people seem to ignore.

The world is facing a grim energy crisis. No one can clearly see the solution being achieved without some contribution by atomic energy. Nobody wants any kind of nuclear threat to the world. Everybody is keen to take the danger of contamination and pollution away from human beings whether they be from uranium or from coal. But nobody wants to let the so-called illegitimates freeze to death in the dark. That is the dilemma.

As to bombs, that matter is an irrelevancy because everybody knows that Australia's signature to the non-proliferation pact means that Australia will do nothing that will enable its uranium to be provided for the creation of plutonium for making atom bombs. As I think I answered a question in this House the other day, the tragedy of the world is that at this moment the major nations have more than enough plutonium to blow up the world many times over. Of course the real threat-Senator Mason and I would share this belief-is that it will get into the hands of smaller countries or terrorists. I acknowledge that very seriously.

The question poses a dilemma and a challenge to the world. It is a challenge that has to be taken up and we cannot just take partisan stands either way. The world is energy hungry; it needs energy. Nobody believes at the moment, with our state of technology, that we can meet that need totally without the use of uranium. I think everybody hopes that the fusion process, the process of releasing energy from heavy hydrogen from deuterium will be expedited and that down the track, say in a quarter of a century, that will mitigate the problem. But, I regret to say that the dilemma on the way is not one on which we can go into opposing corners. We have to try to stop these so-called illegitimates from freezing in the dark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his very thoughtful reply. I draw his attention to the last part of my question which referred to the Kakadu National Park. The implication in that part of the question was that with this reduction in demand there is not likely to be an economic demand for Australian uranium, so why should we exploit the Kakadu National Park further? Would the Minister not agree that there is a case for preventing any further development there at this stage?

—Varying estimates have been made on the world scene of what the demand for uranium will be in the decades ahead. There was some pessimism in more recent estimates but, frankly, countries such as Japan and West Germany and others, whatever their present political policies, have expressed the view that they cannot see how they will solve their problems without some supplementation of a significant kind by nuclear energy. Therefore, I am not of the opinion that there is any proof that there will be a fall in the long term demand for uranium. On the contrary, I think our job is to ensure that if the world needs uranium for energy, it gets it, but under the strict provisions that it cannot be used for non-peaceful means and that the world should concentrate on taking the bugs out of any contamination that nuclear power stations may cause. Equally, the world had better concentrate on taking the bugs out of coal-fired power stations because they are a very real threat.

—My question is directed to Senator Durack, the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I am stimulated to ask this question by the previous one. Is the Minister aware of the forecast that there will be a shortfall in capacity for the enrichment of uranium after 1990? In view of the environmental safety of modern centrifusion techniques for enrichment, and the increased influence and authority that Australia would acquire in the management and end use of nuclear materials around the world if we possessed an enrichment capacity, to say nothing of the employment, scientific and technological gains and an increase in export earnings that would accrue to this country from this action, will the Department of Science and Technology commission a study to consider the introduction of an enrichment plant into Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the feasibility of uranium enrichment is a matter that comes under my portfolio, but I take on board the responsibility of the Department of Science and Technology. Some time ago this Government enabled a body called UEGA-the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia, a body of some four major Australian companies such as CSR Ltd, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Western Mining Corporation-to undertake first of all a pre-feasibility study into uranium enrichment and then to consider whether a feasibility study should be made. The body has made a report. It has said that there will be, in its view, an enhanced demand in the world for enriched uranium from 1990 onwards, but not before. Therefore, there will be a market for a factory producing enriched uranium from 1990. The body considers that Australia has the ability to sustain such an industry. It then outlined the questions of the choice of technology as between centrifuge, gaseous diffusion and a new technology which is emerging called chemical exchange, or chemex. This is an ion exchange and is a very complex process. The body indicated that it would set about looking at it. It has submitted to the Government a report which the Government is studying as to the next step in feasibility.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is confronted with making a number of judgments. I should hope that it would be able to make an announcement in the weeks immediately ahead as to any intention of procedure in feasibility study. There are two factors involved in that. There is the choice of technology-whether centrifuge, diffusion or chemex. Amongst other things, apart from the high technology, the tremendous use of electric power in diffusion and, to a lesser extent, in chemex has to be considered. There is also the question of markets. I hope that we will be able to give a much more detailed answer to the honourable senator within the next few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister or the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It refers to a report in this morning's Age that Australia's top defence advisers have expressed grave dissatisfaction with the recommendations involving the organisation of the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force and the suggestion that the proposition should be deferred until additional questions are answered by the United States of America. Is the report in the Age a fair summary of discussions which took place within the Defence Committee? Did the advisers recommend that there should be a stay in the determination of the force? If that advice was given to the Government before the Government made its recommendation, is the Government likely to review its position following that advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no information on the matter referred to in the Age report. I have no further information on the statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 26 May when he informed the Parliament of the latest developments concerning the proposed Sinai multinational force. In that statement the Minister made it clear that negotiations between Egypt, Israel and the United States on the details of the multinational force were continuing. He said at that time that as far as the Government was aware agreement had not yet been reached on all aspects of the proposed force. He also said in his statement that, whilst Australia had not been formally invited to participate in the proposed peacekeeping force, the Government was aware that Australia was amongst a number of countries being considered as participants.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has engaged in exploratory talks with Egypt, Israel and the United States on the matter. The Minister mentioned that he had been in correspondence with the American Secretary of State, Mr Haig, seeking information on the subject. He also stated at that time that he would continue to seek further information because the Government believed that on such an important issue public debate should be conducted on the best informed basis possible. I will refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs the matter raised by Senator Bishop and the statement apparently published in the Age newspaper and see what further comment he wishes to make on the subject.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES: INITIATION OF CLASS ACTION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Attorney-General. The initiation of a class action in the United States of America against the Alcoa company by the Conservation Council of Western Australia has been condemned by leaders of most political parties, including the shadow Attorney-General in this place. The resolution of this matter could take a long time. Until it is resolved many important projects in Western Australia, including possibly the North West Shelf gas project, are being delayed. Will the Attorney-General outline what the Government is doing to have this matter resolved as quickly as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is deeply concerned about the proceedings which Senator Thomas has mentioned. We are concerned about the issues raised in the proceedings and the implications they have for the freedom of Australian governments and parliaments to determine their own policies in regard to resource development. That has been made clear, I think, on previous occasions. However, we are also concerned with the claim for extra-territorial jurisdiction that has been made under some American laws and by some American courts. I have spoken on this subject on a number of occasions. The Government has already taken action in the previous area of major concern in the anti-trust field. Senator Thomas mentioned the proceedings by the Conservation Council of Western Australia against Alcoa and Reynolds. That raises another aspect of the general problem. The Government has already lodged a note with the United States Department of State or the Justice Department, if that is the appropriate department, seeking to persuade the United States Government to intervene in those proceedings and to make known to the court the problems which proceedings of that kind pose for relations between the United States and Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to that, the Australian Government proposes to lodge an amicus brief in the United States court which is hearing the action. The object of that brief is to challenge the jurisdiction of that court. At present that brief is in the course of preparation. It is being prepared in close consultation with the Western Australian Government, because of that Government's particular interest in the matter. Of course, the Australian Government will be responsible for the carriage of the brief in the international arena. I think the brief will be settled next week. When it is filed in the court I will make a public statement about it, detailing the nature of the case that we will be submitting to the court. At this stage, before the brief is filed in the United States court, I do not wish to anticipate anything that will be in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Communications agree that the observance of common standards of decency and good taste by broadcasting and television stations, including the Australian Broadcasting Commission, is the matter of most concern to the listening and viewing public? Is the Minister aware that virtually no monitoring of television programs is now taking place and that in the last three years no enforcement directives have been made under section 99 of the Broadcasting and Television Act as to program standards? Why has the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal cut by 86 per cent its program of research to ascertain what the public expects from television and broadcasting? In view of these facts and the Government's intention to axe the Broadcasting Information Office, will the Government give a firm assurance that by legislative and administrative action it will ensure that appropriate broadcasting and television standards are maintained and enforced, which it will need to do if it expects public respect for its forthcoming legislation?

—I am sure that all honourable senators would agree with Senator Harradine that the observance of common standards of decency, and proper standards on electronic media, are important in any country. They are important in Australia. Whether or not they are the matter of most concern in Australia, as the honourable senator suggested, is unimportant. The fact is that they are matters of concern and importance. I have no difficulty at all in endorsing his view to that extent. I am unable to give the honourable senator specific information in relation to his question as to whether there has been little or no enforcement-as he set out-and whether a particular budget has been cut. I am unable to tell him but I will try to obtain these facts for him. I see benefits flowing to the Australian public from the maintenance of a system of broadcasting and television viewing which endorses and sets out standards, particularly for those in their formative years who are impressionable. I recall that a question was asked yesterday, I think concerning the Broadcasting Information Office, and I gave some information. It is not that that office has been abolished, but simply that we have not proceeded to establish it. This was one of the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. In relation to the other question the honourable senator asked about what we intend to do to ensure that adequate standards are maintained, I will refer that to my colleague and try to obtain extra information for Senator Harradine.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether it is a fact that Santos Ltd has decided to proceed with an oil refinery at Stoney Point near Whyalla in South Australia. Can the Minister say when this project will be completed and how many jobs will be generated as a result? Can he also say whether this is likely to have an influence on the siting of the proposed petrochemical plant currently under active consideration by the Dow corporation, originally planned to be sited at Redcliff in the Spencer Gulf area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The development from the Cooper Basin in South Australia is of immense significance to the development of South Australia and, indeed, to Australia. The pipeline from the Cooper Basin to Whyalla is expected to be in position by January 1983, which is a relatively short time from now. That pipeline is expected to carry in its first year, not under pressure, some 35,000 barrels of liquids a day-liquids of hydrocarbons of all kinds. It could, under pressure, carry 80,000 barrels, so we are not dealing with an insignificant contribution to Australia's energy or to South Australia's industry.

ANSWER.PARA: It is my understanding that Santos Ltd is contemplating a refinery along the lines that Senator Jessop has indicated. I do not think it has made a definitive statement. Of course there had been a contemplation of taking a pipeline to Stanvac further south and establishing a refinery there. I know that Santos is busy in this regard. I had thought that, due to a number of factors, Dow Chemical (Australia) Ltd had set aside for the time being its consideration of petrochemicals, the stripping of ethane from the gas, but that was governed, I think, by a number of things such as a world recession due to oil prices, and also a development in the Middle East whereby the Middle East oil producing nations, rather than flaring their gases, are now turning towards stripping and processing. In fact there is an emerging glut of liquefied petroleum gas. I should tell the Senate that, as I was fortunate enough to be able to predict some months ago, there is a fall in the world price of LPG of some $40 a tonne, which is very significant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nostradamus?

—It is good when one's crystal ball justifies what one says. I always take credit for the rain. I understand that Dow, nevertheless, is reconsidering the matter. As to jobs, the fundamental need for South Australia is to produce energy by way of liquids and gases from the Cooper Basin. I hope this energy will come also from new coal discoveries in that place. South Australia's potential for job creation is very significant due to great mineral discoveries, particularly those at Roxby Downs, once we can get into place the necessary ingredients of energy. The pipeline from the Cooper Basin is perhaps one of the most exciting things, as a first step, that South Australia has contemplated since General Motors-Holden's Ltd went there in Playford's time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALICE SPRINGS: UNITING CHURCH FRONTIER SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security will be aware of the vital rehabilitation work and nursing care being carried out for aged and other patients by the Uniting Church Frontier Service at the Old Timers' Home in Alice Springs. Will the Government encourage and assist financially to extend this service to other centres such as Darwin, which incidentally lacks such facilities, and the other centres of Katherine and Tennant Creek in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the work being done by the Uniting Church Frontier Service centred at the Old Timers' Home. I was not very conversant with the operations of that place until quite recently when I had the chance to visit it while in Alice Springs. The Uniting Church in Australia at that place provides a very high standard of service to people, some of whom are simply aged, but many of whom are infirm, and others of whom are severely incapacitated. In hostel arrangements the Uniting Church has given a standard of nursing care which, I think, is well in excess of what one would normally expect or require in that sort of accommodation. Representations have been made by the Uniting Church to both the Commonwealth Government and the Northern Territory Government about the need for additional services of the sort mentioned by the honourable senator in his question.

ANSWER.PARA: Some time ago-it was probably a couple of months ago-there was a meeting between the Northern Territory Minister for Health, the Honourable Ian Tuxworth, and representatives of the Uniting Church Frontier Service led by the Rev. Max Griffiths. We discussed the Territory's needs in this area. Strong representations were made to me to the effect that Alice Springs was the only well-served community. I was pleased that at those discussions we were able to meet the request of the Uniting Church to make changes in the arrangements with respect to the Old Timers' Home which, to my recollection, involved changing certain hostel beds to nursing home beds which, of course, has some financial benefit to that organisation and which, I think, will improve the standard of services which can be provided.

The key concern expressed at the meeting was along the lines of the question raised by the honourable senator, namely, the broader needs of other centres in the Territory. My recollection of the result of the meeting was that we reached some agreement. I forgot to mention that the Honourable Michael MacKellar, the Minister for Health, was a party to those discussions. The agreement was that we should examine the position of the Northern Territory, both in the north and in the centre, to see what arrangements were required. The Uniting Church already has proposals for other facilities, for example, at Katherine. These matters are under examination. It is to be hoped that the needs of the Territory in this area can be met with the reasonable co-operation of the two governments concerned and the Uniting Church which has been making such a valuable contribution.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen reports that some 90,000 administrative and clerical public servants will have to wait at least two months to get the full benefits of any wage increase granted to them by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission because it will be a huge and complicated task to process it into the computer system? Can the Minister say whether such reports are correct? If so, are steps being taken in a endeavour to overcome such a delay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware of a report in the Canberra Times, I think of 29 May, with regard to the matter raised by Senator Young. Perhaps I should explain that the article was based on a copy of a letter that was sent to Mr Munro of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. The 4 per cent interim pay increase was not fully processed on the Department of Finance computer. At that time the discrete codes numbers for each employee were not grouped by pay types. This has now been adjusted. The Department will be able to pay the work value increase, if any applies, to the employees concerned from the date of the last basic wage case-7 May 1981-to the date of the award automatically. The Department may be able to take this back to the January basic wage increase but this will involve a few difficulties because of the changes in status of some employees.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Finance system is a payments system and not a personnel system. This is the reason we cannot pay the whole of the increase automatically. The Finance Department does not hold the past pay history records; these are held in the departments to which the employees are related. The calculations for variations relating to overtime, higher duties and status resulting from the three national wage cases must be done by departmental personnel sections. This involves a very heavy work load because of the nature of the changes in the pays that will result from the decision. The adjustment will be one of the largest pay exercises to be undertaken in the last few years. TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Having regard to the quaint conclusions that were reached by a magistrate concerning certain happenings at Ayers Rock, have there been any summit talks between the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and its Northern Territory counterparts to ensure that the conclusions of the magistrate in question are not to be used as an occasion for wholesale fauna carnage? Is it intended that some of the evidence will be probed to see whether people were as truthful as they claimed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may not be appropriate to take up the last point raised by the honourable senator, but I have some information relating to the major part of his question. I think the honourable senator referred to the fact that the coroner, in presenting his findings on the Azaria Chamberlain case, commented, among other things, that dangerous animals should be eliminated from national parks or at least from those areas frequented by visitors. It was these comments which have drawn protests from many people. There is a balance to be drawn, of course, between the need for people who go to national parks to exercise some degree of caution and the appropriate place of fauna in the parks. Following the handing down of the coroner's findings, the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and other senior officers of the Service have had discussions with their counterparts in the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: They have agreed that in the light of the coroner's comments the following action should be implemented. I have been advised of four actions. The first is the erection of additional signs warning of the dangers of dingoes at Uluru. The second is the preparation of a leaflet for distribution to visitors to national parks warning of dangerous animals that might be encountered. The third is the promulgation of a regulation prohibiting the feeding of wildlife in national parks. The fourth is the fencing of a limited area of the camping ground at Uluru within which persons concerned for their own safety and that of their children may camp if they so desire. The benefits which might flow from this approach might well be that people have a maximum of information on which they can base their judgments to make best decisions, that there will be minimum interference with the fauna which quite properly live in the park and that there will be some protection for the public interest, as indicated by the coroner. We have undertaken to make additional capital assistance of $10m available over the next three years. In addition, we provide subsidies against recurrent costs. As I understand it, the problems of Bethlehem House relate to recurrent costs.

ANSWER.PARA: The centre is at the moment receiving the maximum subsidies to which it is entitled. It is operated by the Society of St Vincent de Paul, which is, of course, very active in support of the most needy in our society. The Government increased the rate of recurrent subsidies payable to centres of this type with effect from 1 July 1980.

Senator Hearn also asked whether I was aware of a letter written in June 1980 to the then Minister and whether that letter had been answered. I have made inquiries of the Department. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Archer asked me in the Senate on 12 May whether the Minister for Trade and Resources would, while he was in New Zealand for ministerial trade talks, take up the matter of the impact of New Zealand fish imports on the Australian industry. The Australian fish industry has recently complained about the importation of dumped fresh and frozen fish from New Zealand. I undertook to get a message to Mr Anthony who was at that stage engaged in discussions with New Zealand Ministers. However, the question was asked on the day of completion of those discussions. I was not able to get a message to the Minister within an effective time and the matter was not raised during the talks the Minister was holding on that day. The matter has now been brought to the attention of the Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: I advise the Senate that fresh and frozen fish are included on Schedule A of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. Trade in both directions between Australia and New Zealand is, accordingly, duty free. However, as Australia accords duty free treatment to imports of fresh and frozen fish from all sources, New Zealand does not receive preferential treatment for these items. Australian imports of fresh and frozen fish from New Zealand have grown rapidly in recent years. In 1979-80 Australia imported some 11,000 tonnes valued at $15m from that country. This represented an increase of more than 60 per cent over the previous financial year and imports have continued to rise in the first nine months of this financial year. The Australian fishing industry has the option of seeking anti-dumping action if a case can be established that the imports from New Zealand are being sold at less than normal value and have caused or threaten to cause material injury to the Australian industry. Article 10 of NAFTA specifically provides for consultation between the two governments as a means of resolving such cases.

—May I ask the Attorney where the numbering starts?

SPEECH.PARA: Postponed clause 3 (Objective).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I wish to persist with the Opposition amendment moved in my name to delete all words after 'authorities'. The point of this amendment was simply to clarify the objectives and intentions section of this clause and make it clear that the exemptions elsewhere in the Bill were not overstated in the initial object section. I will say more about the particular subject matter of clause 3 in a moment. However, the point that I want to make strongly right at the outset of this debate is that clause 3 is symbolic of a larger phenomenon that will return over and over again today. That is a situation in which the Government promised to consider the force of the amendment moved by individual senators and promised to go away and redraft the provision so as to accommodate the concern expressed and to bring back a redrafted clause accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3 is the first such example of a promise of this kind having been made. It is also the first example that we will come to today of a promise of this kind being broken in the sense that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has not come back anywhere in his rather tangled amendment booklet, just put before us, with a redrafted clause. He has decided to stand firm on the original drafting. As I said, this is an exercise which is likely to be repeated very often during the day. What might have been a great parliamentary occasion seems now destined to be a procession of capitulations. The Government's will will prevail. No amendments will be carried other than those the Government has indicated it is prepared to accept. However irrational, unreasoned or unprincipled the Government's position might be, all honourable senators on the Government side will line up behind it. As a culmination of the bludgeoning and soothing respectively that have been offered by the Government to its own members over the last few days and weeks we have a situation in which the bravery of three or four weeks has now evaporated. It has got too dark for the schoolboys to whistle any more.

It is true that some significant concessions have been won by those of us who have been concerned to secure more effective freedom of information legislation. Some concessions have been won as a result of the efforts of the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and that original group of Government senators who indicated they had a principled position on the Bill. In that respect the exercise has not been a complete waste of time. There are some proposed significant amendments to the conclusive certificates provisions of the Bill which will represent an advance on the intransigence which originally had been demonstrated by the Government. How much of an advance it represents we will be debating in more detail, later on.

It is now the case that there are sensible provisions with respect to access to personal records for the purposes of correcting them where they are misleading. That is to be applauded. There are minor improvements in the prior documents access provisions of the Bill. For some, at least, that is a matter of joy. A number of small procedural changes have also been accepted by the Government. Many more concessions have been made by those Government senators who originally indicated, by putting their names to the amendments that have been circulated in this chamber, that many more concessions would be made but none of them will now proceed today with the amendment standing in their name except to the extent those amendments that have been the subject of Government acceptance and are likely to be accepted either in their original or in a slightly redrafted form.

As a result, the conclusive certificates provisions are still ultimately in the hands of Ministers. Although there are significant improvements, as I said, that area of the Bill still leaves an enormous amount to be desired. As a result there will be no significant weakening in the scope of any of the exemption provisions which, of course, litter so much of this Bill. As a result there will be not one exempt agency listed in the Schedule to the Bill that will, at the end of this day, be non-exempt. There will be not one class of agency documents listed in the Schedule to this Bill that will, at the end of the day, be non-exempt.

As a result of this capitulation the Commonwealth Ombudsman will not now be able to exercise the wide-ranging functions of an information commissioner that were envisaged and contemplated for him with all the rational arguments that we put together and produced in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. As a result of this perhaps understandable capitulation to the forces that were set to work in the last couple of weeks, innumerable procedural obstacles will still remain in the legislation.

If one looks at the score card, as I understand it is likely to be at the end of the day, the result is something like this: Of the 80 amendments that were proposed and have been circulated, the Government has indicated that it will accept 24, either in whole or in part.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will find you are wrong. I am not criticising anybody.

—We will see. Maybe the score card will need altering at the end of the day. Maybe I will succeed in restoring some fire to the breasts of the dragons on the other side of the chamber and maybe some further concessions will be made. Twenty-four amendments have been accepted. Of the 80 amendments, 56 have been rejected by the Government. It remains to be seen at the end of the day whether they will still be rejected but that is the situation as I undertand it at the moment. Of those 24 acceptances, in two cases they have been manifestly involuntary. They were the subject of votes in this chamber a few weeks ago. There will be a couple of further consequential amendments following from that which, I understand, will also be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be voluntary acceptances of another some 22 amendments, as I understand it. Eleven of them will be accepted in the original form in which they are moved. Another 11 will be accepted in a redrafted form, nonetheless still accepting the principles that were involved in the original amendment. Of the 56 amendments which, on my understanding, are likely to be rejected, 11 are in that category where, I understand, the Government did, in fact, originally promise either overtly in this chamber or outside it that it would take the amendment away and redraft it to make it more acceptable in some respects but that it would basically accept the principles that were involved. In 11 cases, and clause 3 which we are debating is an example of one of those cases, what has happened is that an indication of an intention to redraft has not been followed through and we are left with a straight out rejection.

That is the situation and I suggest that it is a situation which redounds to no one's credit on the Government side. I do not believe that anyone on the other side of the chamber has emerged from this exercise with real credit. The Government has been defeated on the floor, and has been forced to retreat clearly as a result of its concern not to be defeated again on a number of other issues. The Government will win on the numbers today, undoubtedly, if and when divisions are called but it will not have won on the arguments. It will not have won on the merits of the debate and it knows that perfectly well. Equally, as to the back benchers on the Government side who, I know, have a deep and principled commitment to the issues that they have hitherto put their names to, once again we have seen this phenomenon-I have had occasion to draw attention to it necessarily in the past-of standing up but not quite long enough to be counted.

So, we have a situation where the Bill which will emerge from this debate will be significantly better in a number of ways, I readily acknowledge, than the Bill which came to us at the beginning of this year. However, it will-this is ultimately the crunch point-fall far short of what is necessary for effective freedom of information legislation. In this respect the biggest loser has been not any individual senators but this Parliament itself. At the outset of this exercise this side of the chamber genuinely hoped to have a discussion-or a conflict-between Parliament on the one hand and the Executive on the other-a discussion in which there would be a genuine burying of Government-Opposition party differences in a mutual desire to get the best possible legislation in the interests of this nation. What we have instead is that routine phenomenon of an Opposition versus Government debate. That is what we have been reduced to. It is a familiar enough phenomenon in this place but one would have hoped that, in the context of legislation as important and as outside the immediate realm of party politics as freedom of information, we might have been able to do something better. It would have been so much better had things worked out differently. I make the final point that the contempt for parliament, which I regard as having been involved in these developments of the last few days and weeks, is shown by the way in which today's debate has so far been handled-the setting up of it-and the way in which it will be handled. The amendments which have been circulated on behalf of the Government were made available to members of this side of the chamber only--

TALK.START.PARA: —And this side.

—And that side. I would welcome the honourable senator's own contribution on this point if he feels as strongly about it as I do. Despite the weeks that the Government has had to get its act together in determining what its reaction was likely to be, it was only at 10 o'clock last night, a few hours before the commencement of the debate this morning, that we at last had any clear idea as to what the Government's attitude would be on the mass of amendments that had been proposed by honourable senators-particularly Opposition senators-in this chamber. It was only at 10 o'clock last night that we were even able to commence coming to grips with the task of working out what had been accepted or rejected, and what had been promised to be redrawn or redrafted but which had not been delivered upon. Moreover, it was not until the amendments came before us, as is evidenced from what the Attorney has already said this morning about the numbering of the pages of his amendment document, that we saw that they had come forward in a form that can be described only as an unholy tangle. Last night I spent until 2 a.m. just getting the bits of paper into sufficient order to understand precisely what was going on, quite apart from being able to come to grips with the drafting detail and the underlying issues and the principles behind them. Under those circumstances, it will be a miracle if we can have any kind of rational, ordered debate today. It will be made very difficult indeed by virtue of that mechanical failure on the part of the Government to respect this Parliament sufficiently well to bring forward these amendments in a form that is easily and readily debatable.

SPEECH.PARA: Associated with that is the time threat that now hangs over our heads so far as this debate is concerned. We have been told that this is the one day on which this Parliament can have to consider the freedom of information issue, that if the Bill is not completed by the end of this day, if we have not worked our way through all these 80 amendments and through all the clauses of the Bill, there will not be a Bill; that is it, take it or leave it. However, as the Government, everyone on both sides of this chamber and everyone outside this chamber knows, the issues involved in this legislation are phenomenally complex and important, and the most minimum of respect for Parliament and everything associated with it would have allowed rather more time than that to enable a proper consideration of the legislation.

So, today we will go through the motions. On occasions the debate might even be interesting because of the necessarily fascinating and important character of the issues before us. But it will not be a constructive debate because the Government has made up its mind that it will not be. So, effective freedom of information, like, I fear, the reputations of some of those who have been most boisterous in its support, will by the end of this day have died the death of a hundred cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Committee at this stage that we have postponed consideration of clause 8 of the Bill, as is shown on the Notice Paper, and have returned to consider the postponed clause 3 as already amended. You are not planning to close the debate, are you, Mr Minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

In a spirit of charity, I say that the only explanation I can find for his contribution is that he sat up too late last night, not studying the amendments but doing a lot of unnecessary arithmetic which may well prove to be wrong before the day is out.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3 of the Freedom of Information Bill is the object clause. It is an important clause, particularly in the light of the amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act, which Senator Evans supported in this place yesterday. It is true that when we discussed this matter before, I indicated that I would look at ways of redrafting the clause as there had been dissatisfaction expressed by honourable senators who spoke at the Committee stage of the Bill on the previous occasion. I have done that. I have had great difficulty in framing an amendment which does satisfy the need to state the objects as a balancing test. The trouble with Senator Evans's amendment No. (3) is that it does not provide for that balance. It is important, when we are talking about an object to create a right of access to official information, that it is balanced by certain overriding public interests which are embodied in various exemptions. I did entertain the idea that the problem could be overcome by simply saying 'subject to an overriding public interest', but that really is not adequate because also private and business interests are protected in exemptions, which I understand everyone supports.

All I can suggest is that we might drop off the second limb of clause 3 (1) (b). It does not add anything. Sub-clause (1) deals with the protection of essential public interests. I would be prepared to accept such an amendment. I would even be prepared to move an amendment to achieve that. I have not been able to redraft, despite the efforts that have been made to do so, a different form of objects clause. I make the suggestion that I am prepared to compromise to that extent. It is vital, in my view, for the objects clause to express clearly the fact that it is not an absolute right but a qualified right and that there is a balancing exercise that those who will be called upon to interpret this Act must make.
I have seen an alternative amendment by Senator Evans which has just been circulated. Do I take it that it is an alternative amendment to the one which he has moved?

TALK.START.PARA: —For clarification, I indicate that I was proposing to seek leave to withdraw the original amendment which had been moved earlier and to substitute this amendment which is now in front of the Minister.

—I see. That got lost with the rhetoric, apparently. I think that amendment goes some way towards meeting my concern. It limits the exemptions specified in the Bill. Of course, other legislation such as secrecy legislation may be passed which will exempt documents from the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. Although such occurrences may be rare, that could happen. I am sure that such legislation would be vigorously opposed by large numbers of honourable senators. That is simply a logical possibility for which we have to provide. There is that problem with Senator Evans's amendment. I prefer the more ample explanations which are contained in the first limb of clause 3 (1) (b). I think they are more appropriate to an objects clause than the rather terse form in which Senator Evans's substituted amendment is expressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I withdraw my original amendments and move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 3, sub-clause (1), paragraph (b), lines 6 to 12, leave out all words after 'authorities' (first occurring), insert:
'subject to the exemptions and exceptions specified in this Act'.

I do so on the basis that it picks up sufficiently, at least for the purposes of an objects clause, the balancing interest that the Attorney-General, understandably, was concerned to have incorporated in the legislation. The objection he stated a moment ago to a clause in these terms, that it might not accommodate other kinds of exceptions to this Bill which are accomplished by virtue of other pieces of legislation, does not seem to me to be a well-founded point. To the extent that other Acts cut across the principles of the freedom of information legislation, those other Acts are incorporated by reference, as it were, in the terms of this legislation. Their existence is acknowledged in clause 3 of this Bill, which will preserve other secrecy provisions. It is not that I want any other secrecy provisions to have an overriding effect; I am just meeting the technical point that has been made by the Attorney. They are exemptions which are provided for in this Bill. I suggest that the amendment in the form in which it has been moved can be accepted by the Attorney and that the arithmetic can be approved to at least that small extent as a benevolent gesture with which to start the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must make some remarks about this clause. Obviously, there is not complete agreement about it. Discussions have taken place this morning. I understand that the Attorney-General's advisers will consider and may come up with further redraftings. I hope that we will not conclude the debate on this clause now. It seems to me that it is not altogether satisfactory in its present form. I certainly think it should be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: There has already been an attack on senators on this side of the chamber this morning by Senator Evans. I am not going to reply to that. I have not responded to people who attack the position taken by honourable senators, whether on this side of the chamber or on the other side. I will not get into an argument about that. I think that would be unhelpful. I believe that a number of areas that are not covered in the circulated amendments have been the subject of discussions this morning. I am taking a certain stand in relation to this Bill in the expectation that before this day is out we will debate amendments involving a number of areas, including the exemption provisions, which have been mentioned by Senator Evans. As far as this matter is concerned I, and I think, my other colleagues will be supporting a certain package of amendments which the Government is prepared to put forward and to support. I do so because I have in mind that we want a Bill that can pass both Houses of the Parliament and is not therefore just a presentational piece of work which looks good, but which does not have a chance of being part of the legislation and operating in this country.

Senator Evans can insult us as much as he likes. I, and my colleagues, Senator Puplick, Senator Hamer and other honourable senators have sweated over these amendments and what is desired. To some extent we will not be moving amendments which were circulated in our names because we have accepted a lesser package-not a satisfactory package in my view, but one, which, I think, will provide a very substantial gain in important areas. Quite a considerable number of amendments to the Bill have been drafted. I pay particular tribute to Senator Evans and to Mr John McMillan who have done a lot of work drafting the proposals which have been put forward. I wish to say to Senator Evans that those efforts have not been wasted. Today we need to be a bit more constructive about this and, where there are areas of obscurity, we should endeavour to put those aside for the moment and discuss them a bit later rather than indulge in abuse of each other across the chamber. I do not intend to repeat that.

It seems to me that considering the Bill which was passed yesterday, one must look at a clause like this with more scrutiny than is normally the case. Both previous speakers referred to a balancing test. I am worried about that expression. As I understand it and as I look at the need for freedom of information it is a general system of openness of documents in the possession of the Government. This system is not to be balanced by the other, but limited. In some ways I prefer the words which are in the original Government Bill 'limited only by'. These words might have some benefit over the proposal that it is just subject to the exemptions and exceptions specified in the amendment which Senator Evans has moved. Maybe an amalgam of this language would successfully point out that freedom of information is to be the rule, that access to documents is to be the rule and it is limited only by the exceptions set out in this Bill. Perhaps, therefore Madam Temporary Chairman, we can leave this matter as it is difficult to draft on the run. I hope that the Attorney's officers might be able to do something about this. We ought to set this matter down for a bit later in the day and not rush into a quick decision on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to have a second debate on this matter. Perhaps the third time we will be lucky.
—Senator Mason, do you wish to speak?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Madam Temporary Chairman. I think it is quite necessary for me to speak at this stage. There should be some response from this side of the chamber to what the Attorney-General has said. The Australian Democrats question the Minister's sincerity quite seriously on the basis of his own comments on what Senator Evans has said. I say to the Minister that if ever there were a time for some rhetoric on this matter it is now.
—Then let us have it.

—Presumably I can do so without interruption, Senator Puplick. I do not know whether I will. I suppose time will tell. Basically, a deal has been done on the freedom of information legislation in the Liberal Party room. That is the situation. That is the truth. A serious implication of that is that this Government has short-circuited this Parliament, which is the property of the Australian people and to every word of which they have access. This Government has elected to duck out of that. It does not want that to happen. The Government-I include all honourable senators opposite-has decided that something will be done that is to be concealed again. I must say that it is being remarkably consistent, because it is doing so in the consummation of an act which it calls a Freedom of Information Bill. The Government is hoist with its own petard. It has demonstrated publicly and blatantly that it has ignored this Parliament which is the voice of the people of this country. It has attempted in every possible way to dissuade and to prevent reasonable discussion of a series of amendments put forward reasonably, by indulging in a cheap political trick, by saying that it will, in its own circle, to which the public does not have access, decide what is to be done and what is not to be done. The Australian Democrats are deeply disappointed with that.

SPEECH.PARA: My broadsides are not directed at the Liberal senators who have been called rebels-although I suggest that they are not. I think a pretty good cosmetic operation has been mustered on this Bill. They are directed at the Government, which I again indict publicly for striking yet another of the very many blows which it has delivered towards the democratic processes of this country. If the Attorney merely dismisses that as rhetoric, I suggest that that is an indictment of his limitations as a leader in this country. If he cannot see, as Attorney-General of this country, that there is a certain importance in what I have said beyond rhetoric, I feel very sorry for him.

I state for the record that the Democrats are deeply disappointed with the pattern that has been adopted for this legislation. It is a pattern which will not be acceptable to us in the future. In future we intend to see that matters are discussed in this Parliament. I believe that we will be in a position to see that that happens and that discussions will not be curtailed or limited in any respect. We agree that politics is the art of the possible. At this stage it is probably better to achieve a freedom of information Bill of some sort than to have the Government merely saying that it will take its bat home. I believe that on that basis we can proceed today with our operations. The Democrats will proceed to move and discuss the amendments which are listed in my name just as though this place were a real parliament instead of the farcical proceeding which will go on throughout the rest of this day.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are happy for further consideration of clause 3 to be postponed in order to enable further consideration to be given to the language of it. Might I say-I want to make this, subject to further irritations breaking out, the last splenetic contribution but it is made necessary by what Senator Missen said-that the reality is, as everyone knows, that a package was agreed to on the basis of the material before us when we came into the chamber today. —I do not think anyone is in any doubt about that. Senator Missen may have been treated, as usual, with a little less confidence and respect than he deserves by his own Government members. It appears that a few more cosmetic changes of some kind or another will be made, acknowledged or allowed during the debate. But, as Senator Mason says, that will be done only in the corridors and party rooms of the Government. They will not be put on the table here and debated on their merits. There will be further compromises and negotiations behind the scenes. It may well be that the product of that will be some further improvement to the Bill designed, not to get effective freedom of information legislation, but to shore up the already rather tattered reputations of the back bench senators who have been involved so prominently in this exercise. It may be that at the end of the day there will be just a little more icing on the cake, but it will still have a very bitter taste.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General has produced an amendment which will have the effect of drawing the attention of a person to documents which have come in since the 12-monthly publication of documents, schemes and so forth which are going to be made available to people. The Government places some stress on this matter because of the possible cost of administration. Since it is a matter which will be tested and with regard to which it will be possible for this Parliament to take action, on reports, to ensure that it should be done more frequently if there are not those sorts of demands-I suspect that demands will not be that great, unfortunately- we will have a chance to look at this again at a reasonably early date. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support very strongly this amendment to delete sub-clauses (5) to (7). He said:

SPEECH.PARA: These catch-all clauses provide that the Attorney may, in consultation with the Minister responsible for the agency, waive that 12 months period--

if special circumstances applicable to that agency are laid before him. I cannot conceive of special circumstances existing, given the time that all this business has been in train. Senator Puplick continued further in this vein. A few minutes later Senator Missen said: 'I agree with everything that Senator Puplick has said'.
