SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that that comment made by Senator Evans is very unfair. We had a lengthy discussion on clause 8. Indeed this was the clause on which we ended our previous debate. I wished to give some thought to ways and means of getting over the problem of ministerial discretion embodied in it. In principle I am not happy about the wide ministerial discretion here; I never have been. It is the only way in which this problem seemed to be effectively dealt with. I explained what the problems were. The unfortunate fact is that we have not seen a way of getting around them in the time since we last debated the matter. SPEECH.PARA: However, I intend to pursue the question as to whether this will be necessary or whether perhaps there could be some extension for a certain period authorised by the Minister. I am looking at that. Because of the great volume of material and the large number of departments involved here-although substantially it is a tax problem-we have not been able to finalise this. TALK.START.PARA: —The failure of the Bill significantly to extend to prior documents was one of Senator Missen's famous seven deadly sins. SPEECH.PARA: With one minor exception, the FOI Bill will not apply to or give access to prior or current documents in Government hands but only to documents created after the Bill comes into operation. The Attorney-General has met this proposal with one of his own which, as Senator Tate said in foreshadowing our argument, goes back five years in respect of personal documents and does not move back one minute so far as documents generally are concerned. The sort of concession that is involved in the proposal, is, to my mind, a non-event.

SPEECH.PARA: The area of personal records is one where it was anticipated that the existing small exception in the Bill in its present form-clause 11 (2)-would largely apply anyway, of its own right. Clause 11 (2) states that access may be provided to a document if that access is reasonably necessary to enable the proper understanding of another document of an agency which is a contemporary document. Since the usual context in which personal records are sought is the context of getting access to one's personal file, which usually contains layers of insertions extending back over a period of years, with each document being subsequent to and conditional upon earlier ones in the file, it is likely that very commonly personal records, generally, will be accessable under the existing provision in clause 11 (2). The area of personal records was not the area in which it was contemplated that difficulties would really, in practice, arise. Of course, it was anticipated also that departments and agencies very often would be willing, because of the readily accessible character of personal files, to exercise their available discretion under the legislation and effect a release anyway even if it did not formerly come within one of these paragraphs.

As I say, the claim that the five-year backwards extension in respect of personal documents represents a major or significant concession on the part of the Government, in our view-indeed, I think it was the view of Senator Missen when he put his name to the original amendment-simply does not stand up. We welcome, of course, the assurance of the Attorney that in this, as in other respects, where resource implications are an issue, we will have a look at it over the next 12 months or so.

But there is a fundamental difficulty with this claim which will run through the debate today that resource considerations are conclusive so far as the Government is concerned at the moment, and that any provision in this legislation which has adverse resource implications that may require a relaxation of existing staff ceilings and may require the appointment of extra officials to perform functions is absolutely unacceptable. We have a problem with that kind of argument in two respects. Its ideological foundation is, as we have made clear in a number of other contexts, manifestly unacceptable. The Government is applying here, as elsewhere, the razor gang's small government mentality, ideology, without regard to the utility in the larger public interest of the functions that could be served by the extra public servants involved. The other reason for our concern is a much more specific one, that we simply do not believe that in practice these sorts of provisions that we are seeking to incorporate will have the large-certainly not disastrous-resource implications that the Attorney is claiming to be the case. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs was very careful in drafting its report to anticipate this kind of argument, to get as much information as it conceivably could about the resource implications of the various changes that were being proposed. The propositions that we recommended in that report took very carefully into account what we, on the evidence, took to be reasonable resource constraint arguments.

The sort of claim that the Attorney has been disposed to come in here with, particularly when we last debated this matter, is that the Australian Taxation Office will have to spend something like 250 man years in the compilation of indexes and guidelines. Large claims have been thrown around since legislation of this kind was first mooted but have not had any substantial or detailed backing up in any hard empirical fashion. It is just so easy rhetorically to use language and figures of this kind to justify a position which, I suspect, is, in practice, not supported by the evidence but is based purely on ideological considerations. For all those reasons we believe the amendment moved by Senator Tate is an important amendment. It is one that goes to the heart of the practically effective functioning of this legislation and, accordingly, we again propose to divide on it.

SPEECH.PARA: Page 25, after Part IV, insert the following new Part:
''PART IVA-AMENDMENT OF PERSONAL RECORDS
Persons may make application for amendment of record

''43A. Where a person (in this section referred to as the 'claimant') who is an Australian citizen or whose continued presence in Australia is not subject to any limitation as to time imposed by law, claims that a document of an agency or an official document of a Minister to which access has been provided to the claimant under this Act contains information relating to his personal affairs-
(a) that is incomplete, incorrect, out of date or misleading; and
(b) that has been used, is being used or is available for use by the agency or Minister for an administrative purpose,
he may request the agency or Minister to amend the record of that information kept by the agency or Minister.
Form of request for amendment of records
''43B. (1) A request under section 43A- (a) shall be in writing and be expressed to be made in pursuance of this section;
(b) shall specify an address in Australia to which a notice under this Part may be sent to the claimant; and

(c) shall be sent by post to the agency or Minister, or delivered to an officer of the agency or a member of the staff of the Minister, at an address of the agency or of the Minister, as the case may be, that is an address set out in regulations made for the purposes of section 18.

''(2) A request under section 43A shall give particulars of the matters in respect of which the claimant believes the record of information kept by the agency or Minister is incomplete, incorrect, out of date or misleading and shall specify the amendments that the claimant wishes to be made.
Procedures upon request for amendment of records

''43C. (1) Where an agency to which or Minister to whom a request is made under section 43A decides to amend the record of information to which the request relates, the agency or Minister may, in its or his discretion, make the amendment either by altering the record or by adding an appropriate notation to the record.
''(2) Where an agency or Minister amends a record by adding a notation to the record, the notation shall-
(a) specify the respects in which the information is incomplete, incorrect, out of date or misleading; and
(b) in a case where the information is claimed to be out of date-set out such information as is required to bring the information up to date.

''(3) Where a request is made to an agency or Minister under section 43A, the agency or Minister shall take all reasonable steps to enable the claimant to be notified of a decision on the request as soon as practicable but in any case not later than 30 days after the day on which the request is received by or on behalf of the agency or Minister.
''(4) Section 22 applies in relation to a decision in respect of a request made under section 43A.

''(5) Section 25 applies in relation to a decision made under this Part refusing to amend a record in like manner as it applies in relation to a decision made under Part III refusing to grant access to a document in accordance with a request made in accordance with sub-section 14 (1).
Review of requests for amendment of records

''43D. (1) A reference in Part V to a request shall be construed as including a request under section 43A but, for the purposes of the application of that Part to or in relation to a request made under that section-
(a) the reference in paragraph 45 (1) (a) to a decision refusing to grant access to a document shall be read as a reference to a decision made under this Part refusing to amend a record;
(b) paragraph 46 (1) (a) has effect as if ''in accordance with section 18'' were omitted;
(c) the reference in sub-section 46 (1) to a decision refusing to grant access to a document shall be read as a reference to a decision refusing to amend a record;
(d) the reference in sub-section 46 (3) to a decision refusing a grant access to a document shall be read as a reference to a decision refusing to amend a record; and
(e) the reference in sub-section 46 (5) to a decision to grant, without deferment, access to a document shall be read as a reference to a decision to amend a record.
''(2) Where-
(a) an agency or Minister refuses to amend a record pursuant to a request under section 43A;
(b) the claimant makes an application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of the decision; and
(c) the Tribunal affirms the decision,
the claimant may, by notice in writing, require the agency or Minister to add to the record a notation-
(d) specifying the respects in which the information is claimed by him to be incomplete, incorrect, out of date or misleading; and
(e) in a case where the information is claimed by him to be out of date-setting out such information as is claimed to be required to bring up to date or complete the information.
''(3) Paragraph 43B (1) (c) applies to a notice under sub-section (2) in like manner as it applies in relation to a request under section 43A.
''(4) Where a notice is given to an agency or Minister under sub-section (2)-
(a) the agency or Minister shall ensure that a notation as required by the notice is added to the record; and

(b) if any information in the part of the record to which the notation relates is disclosed to a person (including another agency or Minister) by the agency or Minister, the agency or Minister shall ensure that there is also furnished to that person, with the document containing the information, a statement-
(i) stating that the person to whom the information relates claims that the information is incomplete, incorrect, out of date or misleading, as the case may be; and
(ii) giving particulars of the notation,

and may, if the agency or Minister considers it appropriate to do so, include in the statement the reasons of the agency or Minister for not amending the part of the record from which the information is taken.
Amendment of records apart from this Part

''43E. Nothing in this Part is intended to prevent or discharge agencies or Ministers from giving particulars of a notation added to a record in accordance with paragraph 43D (4) (a) to a person (including any agency or Minister) to whom information contained in the record to which the notation relates was furnished before the commencement of this Part.''.

This amendment enables corrections to be made by people who have now acquired the right of access to their personal records in accordance with the previous amendment we passed. This amendment gives them a right to seek correction of any errors they discover and a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to resolve the matter if it is at issue whether the records are correct.

The point of these two amendments is to deal with the question of the time limit within which responses have to be made by agencies to formal requests for access to documents. The time limit provided in the Bill is 60 days. I understand that the Government does not propose to resile from that proposition. The joint amendments standing in my name provide for a reduction, in accordance again with the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, in that period of 60 days back to 45 days, in the first instance, with a provision for phasing in further reductions thereafter. Perhaps the force of the amendment and the reasons for it are best explained, as it is an important one, by my reading as briskly as I can the relevant paragraph 8.42 contained in the Senate Standing Committee's report. The report states:

The unfamiliarity of the freedom of information concept in this country and the administrative pressures-particularly in the present economic and financial climate-that will undoubtedly be associated with its introduction, lead us, however, to be somewhat cautious in our recommendations in this area.

I interpolate that we were more cautious than many witnesses and persons making submissions to the Committee wanted us to be. This was one of the liveliest areas of public criticism of the original 1978 Bill with many persons making the point that 60 days was, on the face of it, an enormously long time. It would give credence and scope for all those bureaucratic tendencies of inertia and lethargy which perhaps come to play in situations like this that it was to be contrasted in particular with the 10 day provision which applied in the United States. Few of our submitters made the point or acknowledged the point that in the United States the 10 day provision in fact is 10 working days which of course spreads out the period a little bit longer. Nor did many people appreciate the point which also became clear on the evidence we received, that extensions of that 10 working day period were in fact very common in the United States particularly in the area of Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation records in respect of which there had been an absolute avalanche of requests over the last few years since the American Freedom of Information Act was enacted. It remained the case, which the Committee acknowledged, that except in certain vexed areas like that, the United States agencies were, by and large, able to come to grips with producing responses in a much shorter period than was envisaged in the Australian Bill. For that reason there was scope for reducing the period in question. A little later in that paragraph the Committee went on to state:

While any figure that may be specified has of necessity a somewhat arbitrary character, we have determined, after full consideration of all the evidence supplied to us on this issue-particularly from the agencies themselves-that the sixty-day time limit should be reduced to forty-five days two years after the legislation has come into operation, and to thirty days after four years. Further reductions, which we would certainly like to believe are possible, should depend on reviews of the legislation as it is then operating. We believe that the initial two-step phased reduction down to thirty days should be specifically incorporated into the text of the Bill. It may be that circumstances will emerge that make the attainment of even these limited reductions quite impossible. In order to allow for this contingency, but to ensure Parliamentary debate of the question while at the same time avoiding the necessity for formal legislative amendment, we propose that any such waiver of the reduction clause should require approval in the Parliament by affirmative resolution.
That states pretty succinctly the reasons for the approach now taken by the Opposition in moving the amendment. The amendments before the chamber embody technical language for that particular policy.

—I thank the Attorney. I will develop the Australian Democrats' reasons for the amendment. This amendment is part of what those of us who looked at this matter would see as corrective surgery on the Freedom of Information Bill. It has the merit of making the whole area more simple and straightforward, at the same time ensuring a reasonable safeguard against excessive demands on the agency or Minister. If carried, this amendment would provide a more easily understood situation at the point of implementation. That is its merit. The point of this part of the legislation is to see that where exempt material and non-exempt material occur in the same document, the whole document should not be denied to the applicant. In other words, it should be possible for the exempt material to be deleted and non-exempt information then to be passed on to the applicant. The amendment is motivated by some words on page 133 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The key to effective operation of this clause is the sensitive application of the phrase 'where practicable'. We can only hope that agencies will apply this liberally, flexibly, and in accordance with the general spirit of the Bill, and take considerable pains to ensure-even if this involves such steps as the masking out of individual paragraphs or even sentences on a page-that the maximum possible material is disclosed.

In the use of freedom of information legislation in other countries that sort of procedure is obviously important, especially where there is such complexity of exempt material as is the case in the Bill as we see it now and, I have no doubt, as we will see it when we have finished with it. I can only share the hope that the agencies would apply the phrase 'where practicable' liberally and flexibly. Would the amendment assist this process? We believe it would by removing a top hamper of verbiage and qualification which is at present in the Bill. Existing sub-clause (1) (b) states:
it is possible for the agency or Minister to make a copy of the document with such deletions that the copy would not be an exempt document and would not, by reason of the deletions, be misleading;

We believe this provision makes it only too easy for a public servant to decide not to make any material available and still live with his conscience. I believe a quite irrelevant issue as to whether a document would be misleading has been introduced. I feel it axiomatic that any applicant for the material would understand that its meaning would undoubtedly change as a result of any deletions that are made-this would seem to me to be square one stuff-and would reasonably take this in to account. The applicant could hardly reasonably claim to have been misled about the nature of the whole document by virtue of his understanding of the residue of it. Could any substantial sections of any document be removed without that justifying the claim that in some respects or other it was misleading? There again, I think that we can see a trap for the implementation of the Bill. This is a problem which at the stage of implementation could cause trouble. The word itself is liable, I think, to quite subjective interpretation. Sub-clause (1) (c) reads:

it is reasonably practicable for the agency or Minister, having regard to the nature and extent of the work involved in deciding on and making those deletions and the resources available for that work, to make such a copy.

I think that this has internal evidence of bureaucratic nervousness on the part of the draftsman. Something is either practicable or it is not. The word 'reasonably' adds nothing to the meaning. The nature and extent of the work and their relationship to the resources available also make me somewhat uneasy. It seems that some very important information might be required in that area which, for some quite temporary reason, perhaps due to staff sickness in an agency, might be refused on the ground of what is contained in that sub-clause.

The Freedom of Information Bill is stuffed with excuses for people not to do what the Bill is expected to do; that is, to make the fullest possible disclosure of information practicable. So the only issue of importance here ought to be practicability. Since this area will certainly concern a large number of important documents practicability should be the only yardstick used. Even then, as the Committee has noted in its report, good faith on the part of the agency will be required. I think that those arguments do justify the amendment which we are persisting with. I commend it to the Committee.

We propose that it be extended to the area of Commonwealth-State relations. In essence it involves an opportunity for someone whose document is called for by freedom of information procedures to put on record his objection or hostility to the document this called for being released.

Those amendments were originally circulated in the names of Senators Hamer and Puplick, but again there seems to have been some resiling as a result of the events of the last few days and weeks. The amendments are all recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Amendment No. (32) in respect of clause 28 in essence is to separate out the national security questions from those related to Commonwealth-State questions and to delete the provisions relating to the Minister having a conclusive right to deny access to such national security matters. Amendment No. (33) proposes a new clause 28A which is a specific provision in its own right with respect to Federal-State relations, again shorn of any conclusive discretion vested in the Minister to deny access to such documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —And adding a public interest criterion.

—As Senator Hamer said 'adding a public interest criterion'. Indeed, Senator Hamer remembers the terms of his own amendment quite remarkably well which is only as it should be because clearly he believes in its force, as I do. Amendment No. (34) deals with clause 29 in relation to Cabinet documents. Here the power of automatic discretion to make conclusive the denial of access is withdrawn. Clause 30 is the subject matter of our amendment No. (35) which is exactly the same kind of amendment, this time in respect of Executive Council documents which are the counterpart of Cabinet documents. Amendment No. (36) proposes the addition of a number of categories of exception from the basic rules so far as Cabinet and Executive Council documents are concerned in respect of matters going to the proper definition of Cabinet and Executive Council records.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular amendments proposed in relation to clause 48 are amendments Nos (55) to (60). Amendment No. (55) removes the reference in clause 48 (1) to the Attorney-General's power to issue a certificate under clause 42. That is consequential upon a proposed deletion of that earlier clause. Amendment No. (56) removes the restriction on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's capacity to review internal working documents from a public interest point of view. In other words, it is proposed by this amendment that the Tribunal have the power to determine whether a denial of access to internal working documents is against the public interest. Amendments Nos (57), (58) and (59) all delete various procedural provisions inhibiting the jurisdiction of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to deal with documents, the subject matter of those earlier clauses, that is, documents of an internal working document character, of a defence or security character, of an international affairs character, of a Commonwealth-State character or of a Cabinet and Executive Council character.

Proposed new clause 48A, which is amendment No. (60), proposes the setting out of the criteria by reference to which it is proposed that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have the jurisdiction to review documents in these sensitive areas that we are here talking about. That formally puts on record the series of amendments that we propose. All those amendments are consistent with the general recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs that there be no absolute discretion vested in Ministers to deny access to any class of documents however sensitive, on the face of it, those documents might be. Of course we acknowledge that the particular classes of documents that are here in issue-defence and security documents, Commonwealth-State documents and Cabinet and Executive Council documents at least-are necessarily of a distinctive kind and a peculiarly sensitive kind. It is for that reason that we propose that the review procedure by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal not necessarily follow exactly the same path as is proposed in respect of other functions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In other words, we are proposing that the Tribunal have jurisdiction only to determine whether the documents in these various sensitive categories were in fact properly so classified. That is at least so as far as Cabinet and Executive Council documents are concerned.

We are concerned to ensure that documents which are not really in themselves necessarily highly confidential, which do not in themselves necessarily have the kind of character which would inhibit the highest levels of decision-making being exposed to goldfish bowl scrutiny-documents which are not really Cabinet or Executive Council documents in that sense-can in fact be identified on appeal to the Tribunal to ensure that there is no excessive secrecy or denial of access in respect of them.

Similarly, in respect of defence, security and international relations documents, we were concerned to ensure that it would not be simply good enough for the Executive officials or the Minister to plant a secrecy stamp on documents, claiming that they are confidential, secret or top secret and, by that means alone, ensure that they are not possibly able to be scrutinised by anyone seeking access to them. We were concerned to ensure, if secrecy was to be claimed in this way, that that secrecy was properly claimed. In other words, we wanted to ensure that the documents in question were properly classified. The purpose of these amendments in this context is to give the Administrative Appeals Tribunal a limited jurisdiction to determine whether the secrecy claimed in respect of those documents was properly claimed in the sense that a document was properly classified. That, in turn, raises the question of whether the Tribunal is satisfied in all the circumstances that the nature of the document is such as to prejudice Australia's security.

Similarly, as to Commonwealth-State documents in respect of which a very large and all-encompassing category of exemption is claimed by the existing Bill, it is our proposal that that be very much narrowed. Part of the combination of amendments we are now talking about provides that it should no longer be possible for State Premiers or any other State officials simply to claim that the document in question was forwarded to the Commonwealth in confidence and, for that reason alone, be able to claim-as is possible as the Bill now stands-exemption from the operation of the Freedom of Information Act. It was our further concern so far as Commonwealth-State documents are concerned to ensure, as Senator Hamer reminded me earlier, that a separate public interest criterion is taken into account and applied with respect to those documents.

Finally, in respect of the remaining category of sensitive documents-internal working documents, which is a potentially huge and catch-all category-it was our concern to ensure that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal had the option and the capacity to determine whether the claim for denial of access to these sorts of documents was, in fact, well made out in the public interest. The force of these amendments was again to ensure that the Tribunal would have the power to apply that sort of criterion. Because at least some of the classes of these documents are obviously very sensitive and because some of them do involve the security of the nation and the secrets of the Cabinet room-both of which considerations the Opposition and certainly the Committee were well-appreciative-we acknowledged the necessity to build into these review proceedings additional safeguards to ensure that confidentiality of the whole process of review was, in fact, preserved. Thus in the case of documents related to defence, security and international affairs and in the case of Cabinet and Executive Council documents, our amendments propose that special procedures are applicable in the case of these classes of documents such that the decision can be made only by a judicial member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and such that the confidentiality of the documents can be guaranteed while that judicial member of the Tribunal is making the determination as to whether access should be refused or denied.

Putting all that together, which is a necessarily complex business that I am trying desperately to summarise in a short space of time, the net result of our amendments is that for a series of four classes of documents-defence and national security documents, Commonwealth and State documents, Cabinet and Executive Council documents, and internal working documents-we want to remove the conclusive discretion to deny access to those kinds of documents which is vested in the Minister as the Bill now stands and to give the Administrative Appeals Tribunal a power to review the claims made. We want special provisions built into the review procedures for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to ensure that in the case of especially sensitive classes of those documents-notably the Cabinet ones, the Executive Council ones and the national security ones-it is a judicial member who makes the decision and the confidentiality of the process is preserved while the decision is in the process of being made.

In a nutshell, so far as I can manage it, that is a description of what this very complex sequence of amendments is all about and what it seeks to achieve. The amendments embody the substance of a very substantial chunk of chapters 15, 16, 17 and 18 of the Senate Standing Committee's report. Obviously they are amendments which go to an absolutely central and fundamental area of this whole question of freedom of information. So long as ministerial discretion in any form is retained absolutely and conclusively to deny access to these documents without being subject to second guessing or review by anyone else, it is our view-up until now it has been the view certainly of Senators Hamer, Puplick and Missen and all the others on that side who have expressed an interest in this matter-that freedom of information legislation is simply not worth having unless we can ensure that documents of this kind come within its ambit, too. Many more arguments need to be addressed to particular points which will no doubt arise when the Attorney explains his own proposal. For the moment, perhaps that sufficiently describes what the Opposition amendments are all about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Canadian Government position is very much like the position recommended by the Senate Committee. The Canadian opposition parties want a de novo appeal. They want a complete appeal on these matters and a substitution for the Minister's decision. We know that the Government in Australia is not prepared to agree to that decision being taken out of the hands of Ministers. There is a need for an evolutionary process to be adopted in these things. A couple of years ago the Canadian Liberal Government was most vehemently opposed to appeals of the nature which are now contained in their Bills. A process of education and experience in what is happening-fortunately in Canada the prompting of some of the provincial governments, such as Ontario, where they are even more prepared to deal with appeals and have Ministers' decisions overturned, if necessary, on appeal-has pressed the Canadian parties to move forward. We have not moved that far here. We will watch the proposals which are made and see whether in a practical sense they achieve these aims. I would hope that we would move in due course to the position which the Senate Committee put forward and which has been explained by Senator Evans. I hope the day will arrive when we can get through the Parliament such legislation as that. I am not apologising to Senator Evans or anybody. I am trying to achieve what is possible in this way and not grandstand about the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is opposed to the amendments moved by Senator Evans. They cover the area of what has been known as conclusive certificates. I have made the Government's view on this known on so many occasions both in this chamber and outside of it and I do not propose to go over the ground again. I do, however, intend to move the amendments which appear on the printed sheet. The amendments provide for the establishment of a Document Review Tribunal which can look at documents of this character and decide whether, in its opinion, the Minister had reasonable grounds for giving his certificate. However, the decision of that Tribunal would be one of recommendation only and not binding on the Minister. The Minister's ultimate power to decide and his ultimate responsibility to this Parliament to justify his decision would be preserved.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the vital stance which the Government has always taken in relation to this class of documents. I am sure that that will be a view that the Government will adhere to. I do not want to have any misunderstandings as to whether this might be something that the Government will be looking at again. This is a very firm policy of the Government. The Document Review Tribunal is to be drawn from former judges of the Federal Court of Australia or supreme courts of the States. They will be judges, of course. Probably there will be only three or a small number, in any case. We hope that some of the most prestigious judges in our community will be prepared to serve on this Tribunal. The Tribunal will be called upon to make decisions, albeit only recommendations, about documents of the most sensitive kind and at the very heart of government-decisions which, as I have said, under our system of government have always been made by Ministers, who are responsible to the Parliament.

I do not see any reason for the chiding by Senator Evans of Senator Missen, Senator Hamer and Senator Puplick, who, in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which they are members, and in the amendments which were circulated earlier in this debate, had supported a wider form of review whereby a presidential member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, albeit a judge, would be able to make decisions that would be binding upon Ministers. I believe this Bill should be the subject of deep consideration by members of this chamber and, no doubt, of another place. I have said all along that I believe there is always a way of overcoming controversies in which there are strongly held opinions on both sides and that these things can be achieved by compromise. I do not believe compromise means one side giving in. Both sides have to give something.

I believe the support that is being given to my proposals by Senator Missen, Senator Puplick and Senator Hamer is being given in the spirit of compromise. I do not expect them to say that they have changed their minds. That would be ridiculous. They have made their views very clear. They have made their decision in a spirit of compromise. I commend them for it. I do not think they ought to be chided for it. There has been a spirit of compromise on both sides of the chamber in this debate. I think that is a valuable part of the process in which we are presently engaged. There ought to be more of it. When Senator Evans's amendments are disposed of I will seek leave to move my own amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an unceremonious way of putting it.

—I mean if they are not passed. It will be necessary for the Committee to reconsider clause 4 as amended and agreed to and clause 24 as agreed to. Therefore I will seek leave to reconsider those clauses as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It scarcely needs to be stated that the Opposition is not happy to accept, by way of compromise or anything else, the proposals that the Attorney-General has now specifically foreshadowed for the creation of a Document Review Tribunal. We will be pursuing our amendments to the point of a division in a few moments. I just make that position absolutely clear. We take this attitude not because we refuse to acknowledge that there is any element of give in the position that the Attorney-General has now espoused. I readily acknowledge, and I imagine that the Opposition will readily join with me in acknowledging, that the proposal for a Document Review Tribunal, an independent tribunal, to make a determination as to whether the documents in issue reasonably satisfy the descriptions in clauses 28 to 31 and to give publicity to that determination is a substantial advance on a situation in which the Minister in question, in the privacy of his own room, can put a forbidden stamp on a particular document and there end the matter. Of course, the reality will be that if the matter goes to the Document Review Tribunal and in a particular case, by reference to the criteria that are proposed for it in the course of these lengthy amendments that the Attorney has foreshadowed, that Tribunal makes a determination that reasonable grounds do not exist for the denial of access and that decision is made public, it will place considerable political pressure on the Minister of the day not to persist in his denial of access to the documents. We acknowledge that and, to that extent, we have moved a distance down the track.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that what seems to be basically involved in the principle of the Document Review Tribunal is the notion that is familiar in our law at the moment so far as deportation matters are concerned under the Migration Act. Indeed, I have an awful feeling that this 'compromise' that has emerged from the Attorney-General owes something to a suggestion that I offered to him some months ago that in extremis the deportation model might be one that could be at least an advance on the intransigence of absolute ministerial conclusivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, that's where it came from.

—I have a horrible feeling, Senator, that that might be so. The system adopted in the context of deportation is that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal can make a determination under the Migration Act that a deportation order is not reasonable in all the circumstances and that determination goes as a recommendation to the Minister which the Minister can choose to accept or refuse as the case may be. That model in the deportation area has resulted in, I think, some 10 or 12 decisions being made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the deportation area which have gone against the original ministerial determination. In all those 10 or 12 cases so far, I think it is the case that the Minister has accepted the determination of the Tribunal, no doubt, because the Minister in those sorts of situations realises the political difficulties he is in if he goes against-or appears to go against in the public eye-a decision of an independent, judicial or quasi-judicial body as this kind.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that some of the same dynamics apply in this area. However, I fear that because of the much greater likely political sensitivity of the character of the documents in issue here, it may be that Ministers will be a little more robust than Ministers for immigration have been in actually refusing to follow AAT decisions. That is the basic point.

A series of quick, more specific points that we wish to put on record about the Document Review Tribunal proposals are these: Firstly, the basic problem is, and always will be, that a ministerial discretion ultimately remains. However one twists and turns, however one qualifies it, however much one acknowledges it-in the way I have just acknowledged that there will be a new level of pressure applied to Ministers not to exercise that discretion to deny access-it still remains the case that the ultimate decision is with them. I do not think-nor did any member of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-that it was a necessary or integral part of the maintenance of the Westminster system over anything else that ministerial discretion of this kind be absolutely retained.

Secondly, if we are to have an essentially advisory jurisdiction of this kind, why is it not being exercised by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, or at least by its judicial or presidential members? Why is it that we are having a proposed wholly new tribunal-the Document Review Tribunal? I thought the Government was against the creation of new tribunals for the hell of it. Is it because we want to get State judges as distinct from just federal people involved in it? If so, why? Who are the State judges that the Attorney-General has in mind? There are some nice, civilised characters around the place in the State jurisdictions, but also, there are some judges whose views, I believe, do not readily fall within the meanings of the words 'civilisation', 'humanity', 'sensitivity', 'discretion' or 'common political sense'. In those circumstances, why is it that we want to have a potentially wider application of membership of this Tribunal? What has the Attorney-General up his sleeve in this respect? Will he be prepared to tell us?

Thirdly, there seem to be some drafting difficulties about the Document Review Tribunal proposal as it is presently before us. Maybe these are easily remedial later on. Maybe there is a short reply that will solve the difficulty. In particular, I make the point that the proposed Document Review Tribunal does not seem to have the same range of necessary procedural powers as has the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. For example, under clause 48 (1) the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has the power, in appropriate cases, to determine that only part of a document is properly exempt and that the other part should be released. On a quick, necessarily cursory, scrutiny of the Attorney's proposed amendment, I cannot find any such power vested in the new review tribunal. I refer similarly to the power that exists for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to make decisions with respect to charges in clause 48 (6), which reads:
The powers of the Tribunal under this section extend to matters relating to charges payable under this Act in relation to a request.

The Document Review Tribunal does not seem to have a power to make those sorts of decisions when the matter lands on its plate. Is there any obvious reason for that? If not, why can we not have provisions of that kind vested in the Tribunal? The final point-maybe this is the answer to the question that I have just posed-is that there seems to be some unnecessary complexity in the procedural arrangements that are proposed. As I understand it, it is proposed that all appeals that will end up with the Document Review Tribunal have to go to the AAT first and from it be referred to the Tribunal. Maybe the view is taken that the AAT exercises, en passant, some jurisdiction with respect to charges and things which are exempt and non-exempt and accordingly it is felt that it is not necessary to vest that kind of jurisdiction in the higher Document Review Tribunal. That seems a remarkably clumsy business to the extent that we have to wend our way through an intermediate tribunal to get there. We are back in this old situation of having a huge multiplicity of procedural hurdles stretching out as far as the eye can see which have to be overcome before the person who is anxious to get his document can get the final decision made. Is it necessary for this kind of elaborate circumlocution to be built into the procedural arrangements that are provided for here?

The final matter to which I wish to refer-I will endeavour to make this the last point that I make in this very large area of controversy-is that I, the Opposition and, I suspect, Senator Hamer, whether he will get up to admit it is another question, still remain unhappy about the Commonwealth-State provisions in particular because--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has said so.

—I know that he has said it in general terms, but would he be prepared to go further and join with me in saying it in more specific terms? I know he is sensitive on the question of State government issues generally at the moment but we will not vest the sins of his family upon him. Will he be prepared to join with me in saying how appalled he is by the proposed retention of clause 28 (1) (b) which makes it a ground for exemption in respect of a Commonwealth-State document that such a document:

SPEECH.PARA: would divulge any information or matter communicated in confidence by or on behalf of the Government of another country, or of a State or the Northern Territory, to the Government of the Commonwealth or a person receiving the communication on behalf of that Government.

What is it that the Document Review Tribunal can possibly do with that clause-that ground of exemption-if Charlie Court, or whoever the Liberal Premier of Victoria turns out to be in the next week or two, chooses to put a 'confidential' stamp on correspondence from the State to the Commonwealth? Will it not be able to rely upon the literal language of clause 28 (1) (b) to say that this was a communication in confidence? If a 'confidential' stamp is put on that document and someone is upset about it and wants access to that document and takes the matter by way of appeal or review-if that is the right word-to this Document Review Tribunal, what on earth can the Document Review Tribunal do when it is confronted with this document from Sir Charles Court which has 'confidential' stamped on it indicating that he does not want this particular information communicated? Is it possible under those circumstances for the Document Review Tribunal to say: 'Yes, we will have a look at this matter and determine whether that confidentiality stamp was properly put on it.'?

What sort of criteria is the Tribunal able to apply in that situation? Will it be able to apply the law, such as it is, that presently exists on the doctrine of breach of confidence so that the Tribunal will retain the jurisdiction to make an independent decision as to whether the document is, in its very nature, of such gravity, significance or sensitivity that it ought properly to be confidential; or will the Tribunal be locked into a situation of simply having to acknowledge the force of the proposition that the document is claimed to be confidential by the State government in question? We are not talking about marginal phenomena here. We all know how Commonwealth-State documents occupy such a huge proportion--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been speaking-

—I am winding up my remarks, Attorney. I have been very good to the Attorney today so he should not stretch my patience either. I am trying to put together in one gulp rather than getting up and down like a yo yo all the dozens and dozens of points that could be made about these provisions. These are provisions on which, with respect, the Attorney ought to be able and willing to give not only us but also the Australian community some answers. These are not marginal, trivial procedural bits of flummery about which lawyers agonise to the intense neurotic boredom of everybody else; these are questions which go to the heart and soul of the potential effectiveness of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will leave the matter there. There are a number of points that I ask the Attorney of a technical character, but still important, about the Document Review Tribunal. I particularly ask the Attorney to give such assurances as he is capable of giving, on the language as it now stands, that the confidentiality provisions will not be capable of abuse in the context of Commonwealth-State relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add a question to the questions which the Attorney-General has to answer. In regard to public knowledge of the recommendation of the Tribunal, as I understand proposed new clause 55V, the regulations regarding the Documents Review Tribunal may in effect apply the provisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Included in this provision is section 35 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act sub-section (1) which states that 'Subject to this section, the hearing of a proceeding before the Tribunal shall be in public'. I know it goes on to give the Tribunal power, when confidential matters are involved, to order that documents not be made public. Assuming my understanding is correct, it is intended that this Document Review Tribunal will give its finding in public so that it will be known to the public and to the Parliament and can, therefore, be discussed before or after the Minister makes his final decision. The section states that the regulations 'may' apply. Can we have some assurance that, in fact, it is proposed that the Tribunal will, in fact, give publicly its recommendation on these documents?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deal with Senator Missen's question first. Perhaps I should have made clear when I was proposing the amendment that it is certainly the intention of the Government that the decision of the Document Review Tribunal should be made public. Obviously, the Tribunal would not be sitting in public dealing with the nature of the documents. So, there may have to be some modification of the provisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. Proposed new clauses 55V and 55W provide for application of provisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act by regulation. So that there can be no doubt about this matter in the future I give a complete assurance that it is the Government's policy and intention that the decisions should be made public. How they are made public is no doubt largely a matter for the Tribunal to determine. That is certainly the policy of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans raised a number of matters, I think the most important of which was his concern about the provisions in the Bill relating to Commonwealth-State documents. It has, of course, been the very firm policy of the Government that any Commonwealth Government documents, the disclosure of which may damage relations between the Commonwealth and the State or which would divulge any information communicated in confidence by or on behalf of the government of a State or the Northern Territory, should be exempt documents and come within this very exclusive sensitive character. I think it is very appropriate that we should have a State Premier in the Gallery at the time we are discussing this matter. Senator Evans's fear is that a State government or a State Premier might so abuse this position that it or he, in a cavalier way, would mark documents as being confidential when they really were not confidential at all. The Government does not believe that State Premiers or Ministers would do that sort of thing. The provisions here for documents communicated in confidence, in my opinion, are such that they would apply and would be held to apply only to documents that really were given in a confidential manner. There is a growing volume of law as to the nature of documents in confidence. Probably, as time goes on, we will have a more refined body of law dealing with that matter.

I believe that the Document Review Tribunal certainly would have the power and, I have no doubt, would report on whether there were reasonable grounds, given the nature of a particular document, for exemption. Of course, if there were abuse of this exemption or if the legal application of it proved to be different from the one that I have expounded, naturally that would be a subject for reconsideration by the Government, and not in three years' time. It would be something that we certainly would look at because it is not intended that that provision would be applied in the broad way about which Senator Evans has expressed his fear. The Government has recommended a special Tribunal for this purpose because I think it has a special purpose. As I said, we want to have the widest selection of judges open to us. I am not prepared to mention names in public because I have not approached anybody, but I have mentioned to Senator Evans-I am sure he would acknowledge this-the names of judges whom I see as the ones I would like to persuade to serve on this Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you consult with me before you appoint them?

—No, I will not give that undertaking. The provision for the appeal in the first place to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal seems to be very complicated. It is hard to explain, but the reason for it is the convenience of the applicant so that when he lodges his appeal it can be determined whether it is a matter which has to go to the Document Review Tribunal or which should stay with the AAT. It has particular relevance in relation to internal working documents. An appeal as to whether it is an internal working document will go to the AAT in the ordinary way and be processed in the ordinary way. It would be only if this particular issue is involved that the document would have to be sidetracked to this Tribunal. Questions of charges also would be decided by the AAT. I do not know whether I have answered all the questions raised on the matter, but I hope so.

Amendment No. (38) relates to a very important section of the Bill which deals with secrecy provisions in other pieces of legislation. The substance of the existing clause is that a document is exempt if any existing secrecy provision specifically prohibits the disclosure of a document of that kind. The proposed amendment builds upon the very detailed argument-I do not propose to put that on the record again-set out in paragraphs 1 to 13 of Chapter 21 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. This amendment proposes to insert in the Bill a new clause which requires that such secrecy provisions as it is legitimate to retain in other legislation be listed in a specific Schedule to the Bill rather than there being just a catch-all picking up of them. It is also proposed that that Schedule be capable of amendment by a resolution approved by both Houses of Parliament. The point is that unless this kind of procedure is adopted, quite apart from the potential for individual secrecy clauses elsewhere to undermine the actual policy of the Bill, there is a basic threshold problem of even knowing what other secrecy provisions there might be in existence that could have potential application.

The Senate Committee identified some 290-odd-indeed many of them are odd-secrecy provisions in other statutes and other regulations lying about in various places. It was the Committee's very strong view that, to the extent that there was justification for these provisions continuing to apply and cutting across the freedom of information principle, they ought to be sufficiently articulated in the Schedule to the Bill and as such made subject to some form of parliamentary scrutiny. That was the proposal circulated originally in the name of Senator Missen. On this matter I regret that once again it appears to be the case that Senator Missen finds himself obliged to succumb to the blandishments of Government senators.

There is a substantial amount of work in going through 294-that is the precise figure eluding Senator Evans-present laws of the Commonwealth regarding secrecy which impose restrictions on some people not to disclose certain documents and different other provisions, many of which are inconsistent in their terms and philosophy with the terms of the Bill. The main purpose of this Bill is to provide $685m by way of non-repayable grants to the States and Northern Territory for the construction and maintenance of roads in 1981-82. Honourable senators may recall that, in June 1980, the Commonwealth Government announced grants totalling $3,650m to the States and Northern Territory for road works over the period 1980-81 to 1984-85. This announcement of funding levels covering five years responds to requests from the States for a longer funding guarantee than has been provided under previous triennial assistance arrangements. The grants apportioned over the five year period are:

I emphasise that these allocations represent the firm and final amounts to be provided in each of the years concerned. They involve annual increases of 11 per cent in 1980-81; 9 per cent in 1981-82; 7 per cent in 1982-83; 6 per cent in 1983-84 and 6 per cent in 1984-85. I should make it clear that the declining annual percentage increases do not in any way signify a lack of awareness, on the Commonwealth's part, of the adverse effect which inflation can have on State and local government road programs. The control of inflation remains very much the Government's overriding concern. It is for this very reason that the Government refuses to encourage inflationary pressures by building into its own expenditure programs open-ended commitments to meet unlimited future cost increases.

In all the circumstances, the Government considers that the levels of roads assistance which it has announced represent a very substantial commitment-one that will enable an adequate level of road construction activity to be undertaken during the five year period. Honourable senators will be aware that an amount of $628m has been available to the States and the Northern Territory in 1980-81 under the Roads Grants Act 1980. By providing for the appropriation of a further $685m in respect of the coming year, the Bill now before the Senate gives continuing effect to the Government's five year funding commitment.

The Bill also provides for limited appropriations to each State and the Northern Territory for national roads in both 1982-83 and 1983-84. These are designed to provide the States and the Northern Territory with an assured basis for entering into longer term contracts for national roads construction works. I emphasise that these national roads appropriations for 1982-83 and 1983-84 should be regarded solely as a minimum planning base at this stage. The amounts currently specified in the Bill will be substantially supplemented when subsequent amendments are made to the legislation to appropriate funds for the balance of the five year program. The total grant of $685m to be made available in 1981-82 will be allocated as follows:
New South Wales-$214.336m
Victoria-$137.828m
Queensland-$139.361m
South Australia-$56.302m
Western Australia-$83.895m
Tasmania-$30.243m
Northern Territory-$23.035m

The distribution provides for each State and the Northern Territory to receive a uniform 9 per cent increase in its grant as compared with the 1980-81 amount. The 9 per cent increase will also apply to each of the road categories for which Commonwealth funds are allocated. The Bill therefore maintains for a further year the same funding relativities as exist in the current legislation. In adopting this course, the Commonwealth has on this occasion accepted the view expressed by State roads Ministers that there be no change in the relative State shares of the total Commonwealth roads program in 1981-82. However, this should not be taken to imply any commitment on the part of the Commonwealth to the maintenance of the current funding relativities for the remainder of the five year program.

The Commonwealth has a very clear commitment in relation to national roads and, in particular, the upgrading of the national highways system. I would expect, therefore, that the distribution of the funds to be provided in the remaining three years will reflect an increasing concentration of effort in the national roads area. To this end, the Commonwealth has set in train a joint examination with the States of options for achieving Commonwealth objectives in relation to national roads. The national roads category will again encompass both national highways and developmental roads. The Bill provides for an extension of the definition of developmental roads to enable some limited funding to be made available from within national roads allocations for significant tourist roads and the upgrading of major development roads in remote areas.

The Bill also provides for a number of significant changes in the arrangements under which Commonwealth roads assistance is to be made available to the States and the Northern Territory. Honourable senators may be aware that the roads assistance arrangements have been the subject of extensive discussions with the States over the past two years. In addition, the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations has recently completed a major report on relationships between the three spheres of Government in the roads area. It has been against this background that the Government has considered the arrangements under which future Commonwealth assistance should be provided. The Government is firmly of the view that, consistent with the Commonwealth's acceptance of full financial responsibility for national roads, it should ensure that its priorities and objectives in the national roads area are fully met.

The Bill provides that grants for national roads construction works will be conditional upon tenders being called and dealt with in accordance with approved arrangements. Our intention to include such a requirement in future roads legislation was foreshadowed by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his 1980 election policy statement. The matter has also been discussed at some length with State roads Ministers at meetings of the Australian Transport Advisory Council. The Government considers that only by the creation of a competitive environment can it be sure that maximum value is being obtained from its very substantial outlays on national roads. State and Northern Territory road authorities will not be precluded from undertaking works using their own day labour forces. It will be open to State authorities to submit bids for the works in competition with private contractors.

The requirement will apply to all works commencing after 31 August 1981 for which tenders have not already been called. Detailed administrative arrangements are still to be finalised in consultation with the States. However, I assure honourable senators that, in administering this requirement, it will be the Commonwealth's intention to minimise any unnecessary disruption of the existing processes for dealing with tenders at the State level. At the same time, however, the Commonwealth will be taking whatever steps are necessary to ensure that its policy objectives are fully met.

The Bill provides for a number of changes in the arrangements covering assistance for roads other than national roads. While the State roads Ministers advised that they were prepared to accept a one year extension of the current arrangements, we have taken immediate steps to further reduce Commonwealth administrative involvement in programming arrangements which are more properly the responsibility of the States. There will be a reduction from four to three in the number of road categories for which Commonwealth assistance is to be made available. The categories will be: National roads, arterial roads, and local roads.

The reduction in the number of categories has been achieved by amalgamating the former rural arterial roads and urban arterial roads categories. This change is intended to provide the States with greater flexibility in the development and carrying out of their overall road programs. Nevertheless, as was indicated last year in relation to the amalgamation of the former urban local and rural local roads categories, the States will be expected to continue to maintain an equitable balance of funding between urban and rural roads. On this basis, program approval requirements are to be discontinued in 1981-82 for arterial roads. These will be replaced with a retrospective reporting requirement under which the States must provide the Commonwealth at the end of each year with details of the arterial roads projects to which Commonwealth funds have been applied.

Provision has also been made in the Bill for the discontinuation of annual program approval requirements for local roads in States where principles governing the allocation of Commonwealth grants for local roads have been implemented. The development of this approach-known as the formula approach-has been the subject of consultations with the States over the past twelve months. Besides simplifying the provision and identification of Commonwealth funding to councils, such an arrangement will provide councils with a greater certainty of future funding levels on which to plan their road programs.

The Bill discontinues the practice of requiring the States and the Northern Territory to meet quotas of matching expenditure from their own resources. For some years now the States have not been required to contribute to the development and upkeep of the national roads system for which the Commonwealth has accepted financial responsibility. It will now be entirely a matter for the State and Northern Territory governments to determine the overall level of funding which they themselves apply to the arterial and local road categories. The Bill also provides that Commonwealth assistance for the arterial roads and local roads categories will no longer be conditional upon Commonwealth participation in State planning committees.

The changes which I have outlined in the arrangements relating to the non-national road categories are designed to streamline further the administration of the roads program. They are consistent with the general thrust of our approach since 1975 whereby we have progressively moved away from the stringent controls imposed on the States by our predecessors under the 1974 roads legislation. The changes are also very much in line with the Government's current rationalisation of responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the States over a broad range of public sector activities. The explanatory memorandum that has been circulated by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) describes in detail the features of the Bill. Therefore, I do not propose to deal with individual sections at further length. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Although I have searched my conscience and initiated open debate on the matter of federal subsidisation of abortions, I have been unable to satisfy myself that I would be acting responsibly or in the best interests of my family or my fellow humans if I contributed my taxation towards abortion.

Besides claiming my civil right not to be an accomplice to what I regard as a mortal crime, I feel obliged to at least offer this action in the cause of human dignity. Abortion is the limit of human irreverence of life. Only holocaust can follow from this point. I claim no more than to be free of complicity from this crime against humanity. I believe this action represents the consciences of vast numbers of Australians who are unable to do likewise.

I have informed and confirmed to the Taxation Department my conscientious decision. Since the Department or the law courts do not have the power to resolve this matter, I have decided to present this submision directly to the Parliament.

I propose that the resolution of this matter will come from a decision by the government to stop all use of public moneys for abortions and abortion related services. Subsequent upon this decision I shall willingly pay my tax dues.
I emphasize that I have instigated this action as an individual and although I support certain organisations which hold compatible philosophies, I am not acting on their behalf.
Yours in Truth, MARIJONAS VILKELIS-CURAS

PRESS STATEMENT
My commitment to fast seven days in public as an act of prayer for all who are inclined to abortion, the abortionists and those in doubt, will officially be complete at midnight Sunday 31 May.

I have now presented myself openly before the Parliament and the people of Australia to express my total revulsion against abortion and the (Taxation) law which implicates me and other citizens in this apparently yet to be recognised atrocity.

I cannot stress strongly enough that with abortion there can be no heaven, no utopia and no human unity-instead inevitable disaster for all concerned. I continue to be amazed at the extent of darkened awareness of this issue, not only with the people but the mass media also.

My retreat-fast outside Parliament House was one of a series of fasts but the first to public witness. I have become more confirmed that my action is spiritually justified although I understand I have transgressed a law of society by not paying my taxes. I am prepared to continue defending this issue and suffer any consequences accordingly.
I pray that we as mankind recover from this disease and gain everlasting immunity.
Yours in Truth, MARIJONAS VILKELIS-CURAS

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring some clarity to a situation in which I feel I have been misrepresented. Yesterday I commented on statements which you, Mr President, had handed down about security arrangements in Parliament House. In the course of those remarks I pointed out that, with all the money we have spent on security in this place, it was still possible for somebody to have thrown an egg at the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in another place. This morning the egg throwing incident was reported in the Canberra Times and my remarks reported in that newspaper made it appear that I felt we should have more security in Parliament House. The point I made, not very well obviously, or the point I wished to make was that I felt we could have looked at the amount of money we have spent on security and perhaps have spent it more profitably in other areas, as people were able to get through the security we have set up in Parliament House. I believe we need less security, not more.
